Hi Mickael, Although I agree change management projects can fail because of people reluctance to change, the question to this answer should be: 'ok but... why are people reluctant to change?' From my point of view, above the fact than most people are reluctant by nature ('the unknown is scary'!!), the way change is prepared and anticipated is usually the origin of this reluctance. A change management action / project has to be prepared the same way than any other project: not in a rush, not after the change occurred (I've seen that) and with a deep work on people mindset and needs, organization culture and needs, to be able to drive change the way this specific organization needs to be driven in it. Careful also while talking about change management failure: as the classic change curve shows, you will always see at least part of the people impacted by the organizational change going through all the steps, from shock, denial, resistance, until they integrate the change, the new culture So this is not failure, this is just the normal path. i hope it helps!

Input.threadtitle: The open talk but rational walk
Input.posts:
I would like to put forward that many executive / board level managers talk an open talk, but walk a rational walk. What I mean by this is that words like 'eco-system' and 'full stakeholder management' and 'triple bottom line' will be used internally and externally, and that the C-suite is very much exposed and therefore aware of the open system within which their corporations operate. However, in the day-to-day management of their businesses the emphasis is on a controllable, predictable management style, that provides scale and uniformity and not the fluidity even ambiguity that would be typical of an open system. So their walk, is a 'rational system' walk.

By nature, thinking is most dynamic, speacially in contemporary days. On the contrary, large companies that thrive are always seeking out new ways to update, upgrade, enhance, sophisticate or change their rationality.

Input.threadtitle: The open talk but rational walk
Input.posts:
I would like to put forward that many executive / board level managers talk an open talk, but walk a rational walk. What I mean by this is that words like 'eco-system' and 'full stakeholder management' and 'triple bottom line' will be used internally and externally, and that the C-suite is very much exposed and therefore aware of the open system within which their corporations operate. However, in the day-to-day management of their businesses the emphasis is on a controllable, predictable management style, that provides scale and uniformity and not the fluidity even ambiguity that would be typical of an open system. So their walk, is a 'rational system' walk.
